Etymology: The oak and other trees, once abundant in the region;alamedais Spanish for "avenueshaded by trees" or "cottonwoodgrove".
Location high in theSierra Nevada;alpinerefers to the Alps or other mountains.
Jose Maria Amador(1794–1883), a soldier, rancher, and miner who, along with severalNative Americans, established a successfulgold miningcamp near present-dayAmador Cityin 1848
Sutter Buttes, which were mistakenly thought to be in the county at the time of its establishment
Calaveras River;calaverasis Spanish for "skulls".
Rancho Colusland grant from Mexico
Location acrossSan Francisco BayfromSan Francisco;contra costais Spanish for "opposite coast".
Location along California's northern border;del norteis Spanish for "northern".
El Dorado, a mythical city of gold, owing to the area's significance in theCalifornia Gold Rush
The city of Fresno;fresnois Spanish for "ash tree".
Dr.Hugh J. Glenn, a California businessman and politician
Alexander von Humboldt, a German naturalist and explorer
Imperial Valley, named after theImperial Land Company
Exact etymology disputed; early settlers believedInyoto be the native name for area mountains, but it may be the name of aMonoIndian leader.
Edward Kern, cartographer forJohn C. Fremont's 1845 expedition
Kings River; original Spanish nameRio de los Santos Reyes("River of theHoly Kings")
Clear Lake
Peter Lassen, a Danish naturalist and explorer

The city of Los Angeles, derived from the original Spanish nameEl Pueblo de Nuestra Señora la Reina de los Angeles del Río de Porciúncula("The Village of Our Lady, the Queen of the Angels of the River of Porziuncola")
The city of Madera, which was named for the lumber industry it was created for;maderais Spanish for "wood" or "timber".
Chief Marin, "great chief of the tribe Licatiut" (a branch of theCoast Miwokpeople)
The city of Mariposa;mariposais Spanish for "butterfly".
Antonio de Mendoza, firstviceroyofNew Spain
The city of Merced, derived from the original Spanish nameEl Río de Nuestra Señora de la Merced("River of Our Lady of Mercy")
TheModoc people
Mono Lake; derived fromMonachi, aYokutsname for native peoples of theSierra Nevada
Derived fromMonterey Bay, which was named for a Viceroy of New Spain,Gaspar de Zúñiga, 5th Count of Monterrey
Disputed origin; possibly derived from thePatwinwordnapo, meaning "home"
The phraseSierra Nevada;nevadais Spanish for "snow-covered," referencing the area's high elevation. The neighboring state was named after the county, which was named afterNevada City.
Oranges, to illustrate a perception of a region with a semi-tropical atmosphere to those from the eastern parts of the United States
Placer mining, a reference to the area being a center of the California Gold Rush
TheFeather River;plumasis Spanish for "feathers".
The city of Riverside, named for its location on theSanta Ana River
The city of Sacramento, named after theSantísimo Sacramento(Spanish for "Most Holy Sacrament")
Saint Benedict(Benitois a SpanishdiminutiveofBenedict).
The city of San Bernardino, named afterSaint Bernardino of Siena(Spanish for Saint Bernardine)
The city of San Diego, fromMission San Diego(Spanish forSaint Didacus)
The city of San Francisco, fromPresidio of San FranciscoandMission San Francisco de Asís, named afterSaint Francis of Assisi(Spanish for Saint Francis)
Spanish forSaint Joachim, father of theVirgin Mary
The city of San Luis Obispo, fromMission San Luis Obispo, named afterSaint Louis of Toulouse(Spanish for Saint Louis, the Bishop)
Spanish forSaint Matthew
The city of Santa Barbara, fromMission Santa Barbara, (Spanish forSaint Barbara)
City of Santa Clara, fromMission Santa Clara de Asís, named forSaint Clare of Assisi(Spanish for Saint Clare)
The city of Santa Cruz, fromMission Santa Cruz(Spanish for "holy cross")
Mount Shasta; the indigenousShasta people
Sierrais Spanish for "mountain range", a reference to the area's topography
Siskiyou Mountains; exact etymology ofSiskiyouis disputed.
Chief Solanoof theSuisunes
Exact etymology disputed; probably aPomoterm meaning "valley of the moon," which references a native legend about spiritual activity in the area
Stanislaus River, named afterEstanislao, a native of the area when California was under Spanish and Mexican rule
John Sutter, a Swiss pioneer ofCaliforniaassociated with theCalifornia Gold Rush
The city ofTehama, probably a native term describing its location
The city ofTrinidad, Spanish for "trinity"
Tulare Lake, which is named after the tule rush (Schoenoplectus acutus) that grew in the marshes and sloughs along its shores
Exact etymology disputed; probably a corruption of the native termtalmalamne,which means "cluster of stone wigwams," a reference to local cave dwelling tribes
The city of Ventura, derived fromMission San Buenaventura(Spanish forSt. Bonaventure)
The Yolan people, a local Native American tribe

Named either by theMaidupeople, a local Native American tribe who live on the banks of theFeatherandYuba Rivers, for one of their villages, or byGabriel Moragafor the wild grapes (Vitis californica) that grow abundantly at the edge of the rivers (uvabeing Spanish for "grape")
